rate.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: the number of times something happens, or the number of examples of something within a certain period
rate.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Immediately his heart rate (=the number of beats per minute) increased.
Australia’s unemployment rate rose to 6.5% in February.
a rapid increase in the divorce rate
areas with high rates of crime
It’s a new technique and the failure rate is quite high.
Asylum seekers were entering Britain at a rate of 1,600 per day.
rate.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: a charge or payment that is set according to a standard scale
rate.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: $20 an hour is the going rate (=the usual amount paid) for private tuition.
another reduction in the mortgage rate
Nurses are demanding higher rates of pay.
Some hotels offer special rates for children.
What’s the hourly rate for cleaning?
people who pay tax at the highest rate
They only pay tax at a rate of 5%.
rate.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: the speed at which something happens over a period of time
rate.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: an attempt to slow down the rate of economic growth
Our money was running out at an alarming rate.
Iceland is getting wider at a rate of about 0.5 cm per year.
rate.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 1: the number of times something happens, or the number of examples of something within a certain period
rate.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: ADJECTIVES/NOUN + rate
Rates of adult illiteracy are still too high.
The hospital’s death rate is the lowest in the region.
a rising/falling rate
A falling mortality rate led to a gradual increase in the proportion of the aged in the population.
the unemployment rate
In April, the unemployment rate fell to 4.9 percent, a 23-year low.
the death/mortality rate
The death rate among the homeless is three times higher than the rest of the population.
the birth rate
In many developing countries, birth rates are falling.
the crime rate
Our crime rate is one of the lowest in the country.
the divorce rate
The UK has one of the highest divorce rates in Europe.
the success/failure rate
The success rate is still extremely low.
the survival rate
The survival rate of twins and triplets has increased in recent years.
somebody’s heart/pulse rate
A miner’s resting heart rate can be between 40 and 60 beats a minute.
metabolic rate
Metabolic rate rises with any form of activity.
the rate goes up
The crime rate just keeps going up.
the rate goes down
We are expecting unemployment rates to fall.
rate.translation[0].note_box[1].heading: – Meaning 2: a charge or payment that is set according to a standard scale
rate.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: You ought to switch to an account that pays a higher rate of interest.
Wage rates in the industry are still too low, he says.
a special/reduced rate
Reduced rates are available for groups of 10 or more visitors.
the hourly/weekly rate
Women have lower hourly rates of pay than men.
the going rate
She could not afford to pay them the going rate.
a flat/fixed rate
Profits were taxed at a flat rate of 45 percent.
the interest rate
Interest rates have remained high.
a mortgage rate
Higher mortgage rates should slow down the rapid rise in house prices.
a tax rate
People objected to higher property tax rates.
the exchange rate
the exchange rate between the dollar and sterling
the wage rate
What is the hourly wage rate?
the base rate
The interest charged on your overdraft changes in line with bank base rates.
the prime rate
The amount above the prime rate is determined by the bank’s assessment of the risk involved in making the loan.
the rate of interest/pay/tax etc
They believe that Labour would raise the basic rate of tax.
at a rate of
Some customers are paying interest at a rate of over 15%.
raise/put up the rate
If the banks raise interest rates, this will reduce the demand for credit.
cut/reduce/lower a rate
The Halifax Building Society is to cut its mortgage rate by 0.7 percent.
rate.translation[0].note_box[2].heading: – Meaning 3: the speed at which something happens over a period of time
rate.translation[0].note_box[2].sections: The urban population has grown at a faster rate than the rural population.
The plant’s ability to thrive in these conditions is partly due to its rapid rate of growth.
The alarming rate of increase in pollution levels has concerned environmentalists.
He started to produce movies at a tremendous rate.
We are losing species at an unprecedented rate.
The process takes place at a constant rate.
rate.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to think that someone or something has a particular quality, value, or standard
rate.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: The company seems to rate him very highly (=think he is very good).
Rhodes is currently rated the top junior player in the country.
rate.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to be considered as having a particular quality, value, or standard
rate.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: That rates as one of the best meals I’ve ever had.
rate.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: if you rate someone or something, you think they are very good
rate.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: They rate a big thank-you for all their hard work.
a local incident that didn’t rate a mention in the national press
rate.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: a charge or payment fixed according to a standard scale
rate.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: We have advised  (=informed) our client of your  hourly rate.
The councils have powers to set minimum rates of pay.
I’m told $25 an hour is the going rate (=the usual amount paid) for private tuition.
rate.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: the number of examples of something or the number of times something happens, often expressed as a percentage
rate.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: Canada’s unemployment rate rose to 8.3% of the working population in August.
The pension finding service has an 87% success rate.
The failure rate of small businesses is notoriously high.
rate.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: the speed at which something happens
rate.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: Companies have been going out of business at an incredible rate (=very fast).
rate.translation[2].definitions[3].defin: the part of your income or the part of the price of something that you pay in tax
rate.translation[2].definitions[3].examp: Those who earn $180,000 to $280,000 will see their tax rates drop to 31% from 33% this year.
rate.translation[2].definitions[4].defin: the percentage charged for borrowing money, or a percentage you receive when you put money in a bank, make an investment etc
rate.translation[2].definitions[4].examp: Interest rates are falling and now is the time to buy property.
The rate on the bank’s standard credit cards will be 18.9%.
Mortgage rates will fall; corporate bond rates will fall; municipal bonds rates will also fall.
the most recent changes in the short and long rates (=the rates for borrowing over short and long periods of time)
rate.translation[2].definitions[5].defin: the amount you have to pay for insurance
rate.translation[2].definitions[5].examp: Women drivers get cheaper insurance rates because their accident records are better.
rate.translation[2].definitions[6].defin: a payment for a public service, usually based on the value of the property owned by the person who uses the service
rate.translation[2].definitions[6].examp: a non-domestic water rate of 3.4 pence in the pound
rate.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: to think that someone or something has a particular quality, value, or standard
rate.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: The Salzburg Sheraton is rated as one of the city’s best hotels.
His employer rates him very highly.
rate.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: to be considered as having a particular quality, value, or standard
rate.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: It rates as one of the most comfortable PC keyboards I’ve tried.
The SLR can hardly be rated as a precision piece of equipment.
rate.translation[3].definitions[2].defin: to measure the risk of investing in or lending to a company, local authority etc
rate.translation[3].definitions[2].examp: Moody’s Investors Service Inc. has rated the bonds single-A-1.
Richard Simon of Goldman Sachs has rated Paramount stock a ‘hold’ for the past year.
rate.translation[3].definitions[3].defin: to measure the performance of a ship or machine so it can be put in a particular class
